text: Home video footage of an African-American HAND holding up TUXEDO. We hear the elderly voice of its owner: CECIL V.O. This was the tux I wore on my first day workin’ at the White House on September 8, 1957. The video camera pans over to CECIL GAINS, 90, African- American. He is a kind, gentle soul wearing comfy sweatpa and a sweatshirt. We hear the male voice of the CAMERA MA
Who was your favorite president? Cecil smiles. He would never say who his favorite was.
I liked them all very much.
Even Nixon?
I especially liked Mr. Nixon, and Mrs. Nixon was just lovely.
What about LBJ? Cecil starts to laugh.
Well, he was...different, that’s fo’ sure, but a very special man.
Did you ever meet a person you didn’t like? Cecil thinks about it, then his smile slowly drops.
If the Devil wore a green bow in his hair, the good Lord woulda’ named him Annabeth Lewis.
ANNABETH LEWIS, 45, white, plump, wears a lacy dress and green bow in her hair. She screams at a young Cecil, 8.

Every single field nigger on this farm wants to work inside the house! Why in the name of the lord and sweet baby Jesus should I take a puny little nigger like you?! Terrified, little Cecil stares out at thirty black FIELD WORKERS picking cotton in the hot sun.
My ma just passed and my pa been gone a long tim--
Boo hoo! Little nigger don’t have no kin! Give me a real reason, boy! Little Cecil shivers, terrified:
Cuz...cuz...I think yo’ green bow is awful nice, Mrs. Lewis. Her face turns bright red in anger.
Annabeth is in the kitchen arranging chicken with lemon slices on an ornate gold tray. Cecil pays close attention

When you're servin’ you need to be as quiet as you can. I don’t even want to hear you breathe. A little scared, Cecil nods. ANNABETH WILLIAMS (CONT’D) The room should feel emptier when you're in it cuz no one likes a nigger. You understand me, boy? Cecil nods with simplicity, he understands.

Cecil stands behind Annabeth holding a bowl of potatoes t she scoops on to her HUSBAND and three pre-teen SON’S pla Cecil holds his breathe, struggling to not make a peep. Annabeth serves with a distinct elegance, very delicate. Cecil closely eyes her every move as he quickly sips a ti breathe, then looks around to see if anyone noticed.

Little Cecil lies awake in a tin shack filled with five o sleeping African-Americans of all ages. Everyone is cramm on the dirty floor, barely able to stretch their legs out Lying on his back, Cecil mimes pouring water. Practicing.
Cecil pours iced tea for Annabeth who reads Marie Curie’s autobiography. He puts in two spoon fulls of sugar and st
This is the one day I don’t want sugar. Make me another. Disappointed, Cecil takes the glass and walks away.
Cecil walks back in with another iced tea.
Is there honey in it? The look on his face clearly says no.
He walks back in and places another iced tea next to her. ANNABETH LEWIS (CONT’D) I’ve decided I don’t want honey, I want sugar after all.

I brought it plain along with some options, Mrs. Lewis.  He gestures in Annabeth’s stylish manner toward the tray where there is a filled sugar bowl, a tiny jar of honey, lemon and lime slices, marble tea cakes and oatmeal cooki Annabeth forces herself not to smile as she gives Cecil a slight head bow. He is stunned at the first positive gest
There are no stirring spoo-- But Cecil is already stirring it with a silver stirring spoon. He sets it on a tray, then gives a slight head bow ANNABETH LEWIS (CONT’D) Do you read, Cecil?
No, Mrs. Lewis. She goes back to her book, flicks her hand at him to leav

Cecil walks into the family library filled with leather b books. He opens a book and stares at the maze of words. W hear 90 year old Cecil in V.O.: CECIL V.O. I'd never seen anything so confusing in all my life.
Cecil sits in the corner as everyone sleeps. Using a cand he places his finger under each word, silently mouthing i CECIL V.O. But after awhile I started to get it.

Cecil is now 15 years old. He sits on the back porch eati grungy meat and potatoes next to the family dog, reading copy of ‘Huckleberry Finn’. He looks up from the book, sa CECIL V.O. Those books ended up being the worst thing to ever happen to me.
Cecil walks around the cotton field, he looks deeply unha CECIL V.O. Until I started readin’, I always thought the world ended at the edge of the cotton farm.

Annabeth and Cecil serve the family. Annabeth sets fish o plate and Cecil debones it like a pro. A well oiled duo. CECIL V.O. I decided I wasn’t gone read no mo’ books. Annabeth has a huge fake smile, a servant in her own fami
But it was too late...
Seated at her chair, Annabeth stares up at Cecil, can’t believe what she’s just heard. She looks almost sad.
But...why?
I wanna see some of the things I been readin’ about. I been savin’ up for almost three year now. Her face becomes very stoic. She goes back to her book.

That's fine. Leave when you like. She flicks him away. He stares at her, surprised and hurt that this is it after all these years. He walks to the do ANNABETH LEWIS (CONT’D) Cecil. Cecil stops, looks back at her. There are tears in her ey ANNABETH LEWIS (CONT’D) I wanted to be a paleontologist.

Cecil rides the rails in a freight train car with a knaps He stares at the barren landscape that flies by, enthrall Seated across from him are two grimy HOBOES, white. Excit by the ride, Cecil smiles at them...they don’t smile back
Sunlight beams in on a sleeping Cecil, blood CAKES his he He struggles to wake up as he feels the pain. He darts aw as he looks around - everything he has is gone.

Walking down a dirt road with a blood soaked rag to his h he passes a charred abandoned factory with broken windows CECIL V.O. I started to understand why they were callin’ it a Depression. A PRISON TRUCK drives by full of BLACK PRISONERS, all cha together. Cecil stares at the truck, scared this will be
A line of ragged looking white men, women and kids, are l up in a grimy bread line. They SCREAM and hiss at Cecil.

Go away!/Leave here!/Die, nigger! Little kids throw stones and rocks at him. Cecil runs awa INT. TIN SHACK — DAY A rainstorm hammers down upon Cecil who cradles himself i small tin shack. Water drips on his head. Drip Drip Drip. CECIL V.O. I would dream I was cleaning gold flatware... He looks like he’s slowly going mad. Drip Drip Drip.

Cecil stumbles in to a country town through pouring rain. peers in a window of a closed country store, sees groceri CECIL V.O. .+-and serving chicken au poivre from a silver tray. Transformed into a depraved soul, he finds a large rock, picks it up to throw it through the window... .--but he suddenly STOPS as he sees a glow in the distanc He slowly walks through the rain toward the glowing light The closer he gets, the more his eyes fill with fascinati He walks right up to an ornate glass window at a beautifu Southern HOTEL. Through the window he sees... Three BLACK MEN in elegant black tuxedos. They are placin gold forks next to china dishes in an opulent dining room
Having cleaned up a touch, he is in the kitchen of the ho The HEAD BUTLER, black, 40's, glares at him with a meanne
So tell me, boy, why in the hell should I hire you!? Cecil turns to him with a warm smile, completely at ease.
I have found that it is better to serve, than be served. The Head Butler tries not to smile.
90 year old Cecil is seated on a chair, still being filme
When did you end up in DC?
Ah, come on now. I got to start gettin’ ready for tonight.
Just a few more questions.  Cecil sighs, resigned.
I got to Washington DC about ten years later. I went there to enlist so I could fight in the war...

A WEALTHY COUPLE walks in to the grand lobby of the Hotel Waiting for them with scotch on a silver tray is Cecil, n 25. He wears a black vest and tie, exudes class and grace CECIL V.O. ...but the army wasn’t so interested in takin’ negroes.
Cecil delicately pours red wine into a glass decanter, a candle under it to see the sediments more clearly. CECIL V.O. And the negroes they did take, they only used for cleanin’ and servin’.
Cecil shakes a martini shaker with grace and style. He tw off the top and effortlessly pours the martini into a gla CECIL V.O. But I wouldn’t have minded.

Cecil hangs a guest’s suit and shirt into the closet, the checks the buttons on the shirt, one at a time. CECIL V.O. I would've been happy servin’ a Colonel escargot in France... Discovering one of the buttons is loose, he pulls out a needle and thread from his pocket and begins to re-sew it
...or pouring a General jasmine tea in Tokyo. Then, he hears CRYING in the next room. He peaks in and the shy maid, GLORIA, 22, black, crying on the floor.
What’s the matter, Gloria? She holds up a white dress shirt covered in a red wine st
The glass slipped. (Starts crying again) I can’t lose this job, Cecil.
Cecil holds the shirt under the sink as he vigorously rub bar of soap over the stain. She watches him, impressed.
There's magic in a simple bar of soap, but it only works if the water is real hot. He holds it up, the stain is coming out. She smiles.
Everyone say you real kind.
Ah, it ain’t nothin’. But she keeps smiling at him...
Gloria stands in front of a PASTOR, wears a wedding dress
I do. CUT TO - CECIL. He is next to her, looks slightly terrifi
I do.

A wedding reception is being held in the basement. A jazz band plays as dozens of people dance, drink and celebrate  10. CECIL V.O. I didn’t have no kin folk there, but Gloria sho’ made up for it. Cecil walks around serving cocktails. Gloria hurries over takes the tray. He shrugs, embarrassed, just can’t help i She escorts him to the dance floor as the band plays a sl tune. They slow dance, foreheads touching, madly in love.
Should I bring out hors devours? She shakes her head, no. Kisses him on the mouth.
Cecil carries Gloria into their honeymoon suite, a dank r with dirty carpets. They look like they are in Heaven.
They lie in bed next to each other, cuddling. Gloria look blissful, but Cecil seems pensive.
What’s wrong, baby doll?
I was just thinkin’ about Annabeth Lewis.
That mean ole cracker woman?
I feel so sad for her. (Turns to Gloria) She neve’ had no one love her the way I’m gonna love you. Gloria starts to beam.
I’m gonna give you a house and a family and I’m gonna take care of us for the rest of our lives. Nothin’ ever gonna tear my family apart. You hear me, honey bear?
I hear you, baby doll.  11.
Cecil changes his clothes in the run down locker room. Th HOTEL MANAGER, 50’s, white, walks in. He looks concerned.
Cecil, there’s a problem.
What is it?
Gloria is in the hospital.
Cecil stands outside the hotel trying to hail a taxi, but none will stop. Panicked, he sees the Wealthy Couple gett into a Bentley. An awkward look as they know he needs a r
Cecil runs down a street waving at cabs that won’t stop. sprints past a store with a ‘WHITES ONLY’ sign on it.
Cecil runs past the US Capitol Building.
He runs past the Supreme Court of the United States.
He hurries down the hallway of a dilapidated hospital, fi the door he’s looking for. A young NURSE, black, stops hi
You can’t go in there. She needs rest.
Please, I need to see her--
I said ya can’t go-- But he moves past her and hurries in to the room.  12.
Lying on a hospital bed in a room with four other PATIENT Gloria, she looks terrible, exhausted. Cecil hurries to h
You okay, honey bear?
Your son came early, baby doll. Tears fill his eyes at the news.
It’s a boy? She nods.
And he don’t wait for no one.
Cecil is in the hospital nursery holding his newborn baby who cries with all the other newborns. Cecil is in love.
I promise I’1l never leave you, Louis. His son continues to cry.
Nothin’ ever gonna tear us apart.

The Gains house is packed with many NEIGHBORS, all Africa American, as Cecil walks around serving all of his friend fried chicken, biscuits and corn on the cob on a silver t CECIL V.O. Everything was real nice for a long time. Seated by himself in the corner is LOUIS, now 12 years ol little chubby, he reads a comic book.

You wanna join the group, Louis?  13. Cecil nods to the BOYS seated in the living room. Louis shrugs, ‘not really’. Cecil gives him an understanding wi A fun neighbor, HOWARD, 40’s, charismatic, grills the boy
What do you want to be when you grow up, Elroy? A small boy in army fatigues, ELROY, 8, points at Cecil.
I wanna work at a fancy hotel just like Mr. Gains. The room ‘ahhhs’ as Elroy’s mom, GINA, heavy, smiles.
That’s my boy.
What about you, Louis? You want to work at a hotel like your dad? The room turns to Louis who looks unsure, a touch lost.
I...I don’t know. There is a moment of silence, Cecil looks almost embarras
That's alright, Louis, you take your time. Cecil smiles at Louis, but it’s clear there’s the slighte ounce of concern for his son who’s a touch different.
Holding a tray of martinis, Cecil approaches a table of WEALTHY MEN. A man with CREW CUT, 40’s, stern, searches h pocket for matches as he listens to a LOUD PATRON.

The best decision that court ever made was to slow the whole mess down. Nigger boys in school with white girls?! Hell, we’d have another civil war! He sets his scotch down close to the table’s edge. Cecil glances at it, then notes how full the other glasses are.  14. LOUD PATRON (CONT’D) Cecil, what do you think of nigger kids in school with white folks? All eyes turn to Cecil, the Crew Cut Man paying particula attention as he keeps searching for matches.
(Refined voice) To be honest, Mr. Jenkins, I tend not to be too concerned with American or European politics. The Crew Cut Man smiles, liked the answer.
Nor should you, Cecil, they’re all criminals. Earl Warren should be hanged. He’s the dumb son-of-a- bitch judge that said it was okay to integrate the schools.
I think Judge Warren is going to find that quite a challenge.
Damn, straight, Cecil! He pats Cecil on the back, knocking the scotch off the ta In one motion, Cecil CATCHES it, places it in on the tabl and LIGHTS the Crew Cut Man’s cigar with his other hand.
More spirits, gentleman? Puffing out smoke, the Crew Cut Man grins at Cecil. CECIL V.O. I didn’t know it then...
90 year old Cecil stares forward, lost in thought.
..-but things were about to change.
Seated by himself reading a comic book, Louis notices a g of kids huddled around something. He walks over to them.  15.
What are ya all lookin’ at? A TEEN holds up a copy of Jet Magazine opened to a grueso picture of a black teen boy’s CORPSE with a mutilated fac
Who’s that?
Emmet Till. Some crackers did this to ‘em in Mississippi for talkin’ to a white girl.
How old was he?

Fourteen. Louis can’t help it, he starts to cry. INT. CECIL’S CAR - DAY Cecil drives Louis home from school in his Ford 2 door. L stares in silence at his lower class neighborhood of smal but lively storefronts - grocers, liquor stores, restaura
I’m sorry I got so upset at school.
That magazine neve’ shoulda published that picture. They should be ashamed of themselves. Louis looks at his father.
Why did they kill him?
Who?
Emmet Till. He didn’t do nuthin’. Cecil doesn’t answer at first. Then -
The law is different fo’ colored folk than it is fo’ white folk. (MORE )
There's certain things that colored folk can’t do or say. (Then) Never get in trouble with the law, Louis, and you’ll be just fine. Louis stares at him, uneasy with what his dad just told h
Cecil is changing into his street clothes when the Hotel Manager sticks his head into the room, he looks concerned
Are you in trouble with the law?
No, sir.
The Secret Service just called me asking about you. Cecil stares at him, baffled.

Cecil walks up to the Blair House, a federal-style townho that faces the WHITE HOUSE. He glances at the White House takes a breath, then walks into the Blair House. INT. FREDDIE FALLOW’S OFFICE - BLAIR HOUSE - DAY Cecil sits in a small office, finely furnished with turn the century antiques. He sits across from FREDDIE FALLOWS black, mid-50’s, has the formality of English royalty.
Are you political, Mr. Gains?
No, sir.
Good, we have no tolerance for politics at the White House. Slight beat.  17.
Forgive me for asking, but how did you find me?

(Icy) I didn’t. You served RD Warner at the Excelsior Hotel a few years ago. He is the Chief Usher here which means he oversees operations for the entire House. Needless to say, you made quite an impression.
A few years ago?
Mr. Warner and myself make note of potential staff around town, but butler positions rarely open as most stay on for 30 years or more.
I see. It was quite a surprise getting the call.
It was a surprise for me as well. As the White House Maitre D’, I normally hire the butlers. Cecil immediately knows that Freddie doesn’t want him.
Forgive me for saying this, Mr. Fallows, but I certainly wouldn't want to be hired under circumstances that would make you uncomfortable.
You wouldn’t?

Absolutely not. Your job must be immensely challenging, serving the President of the United States. You need butlers that you’ve hand picked, men to your liking that will fulfill your vision of a proper White House staff. Cecil glances at a collection of crystal doves on his des  18.
Are these baccarat? Freddie looks surprised.
Indeed.
Waterford is pleasant, and the Irish certainly make a great whiskey, but I think the French have a distinct advantage when it comes to crystal. Freddie stares at Cecil for a beat. Then:
Would you care for a demitasse?
Gloria, Louis, Gina and Elroy and several neighbors are a in the living room, waiting. Elroy is very excited, but L looks indifferent, reading a book. From upstairs they hea

Y'all ready? They all shout ‘yes’ in unison. Cecil slowly walks down t stairs. They first see his shiny shoes, then his sleek pa and finally the full view - a perfectly tailored tuxedo. The entire room applauds as Gloria tears up, so proud.
My baby is the President’s butler. Elroy is in total awe, but Louis looks a little uneasy.
Cecil is in his car in the employees parking lot that overlooks the South Lawn, directly behind the White House gets out and looks around, eyes peeled open in awe.
Cecil walks down a treeline pathway toward the side entra where flags stick out of lamp posts. He stops at the Secu Gate, a shed with a glass window.  19.
My name is Cecil Gains. I’m the new butler.

Cecil and Freddie walk through the elegant first floor of entrance hall. Marble walls with red carpet and pink tile floors, a French palace and a museum rolled into one. Four HOUSEMEN, all black, late 20's, are setting up ropes barriers and tables for the White House tour.
We have six houseman who are primarily responsible for furniture and chair arrangements.
Six men just to move the tables? Freddie gives him a ‘you have no idea’ look.
There are over 70 full time employees at the House. They walk the Cross Hall passing the Presidential portrai

16 maids, 6 butlers, 4 carpenters, 2 painters, 7 electricians, 9 engineers, 2 plumbers, 2 grounds keepers, 3 florists, 2 pantry men, 3 dishwashers, 3 doorman, 4 florists, a full kitchen staff including pastry chef and 3 full time calligraphers. Freddie nods at a small MAN who sets a clock in the hall.
And Joe sets all the clocks.
That’s his only job?
Every hour of every day, he makes sure that every clock is set to the exact time.  20. The Crew Cut Man from the hotel, RD WARNER, walks by. Cec eyes light up, he steps forward.
Mr. Warner, I just want to thank you for this opportuni-- But RD Warner keeps walking, doesn’t even acknowledge him Cecil is surprised by the snub. Freddie whispers in his e

The Chief Usher is not overly friendly with the colored help. Cecil nods, he gets it. INT. WHITE HOUSE - BUTLER’S LOCKER ROOM - MORNING Cecil enters the plain locker room with chipped benches. butlers are changing into tuxes, BOOKER PARKER, 32, short fiery, and CARTER WILSON, 40, stocky with a solemn demean
Ten to one those kids never see the inside of that classroo--. They immediately clam up as they see Cecil. Eyeing the ne guy. Cecil holds out his hand.
I’m Cecil Gains, the new butler. Carter shakes his hand first.
Carter Wilson, head butler and this is Booker Parker, second butler.
Where ya stand on civil rights, blood? Cecil is taken back. Carter shoots Booker a frustrated lo
Why don’t you shake the man’s hand first? Booker holds out his hand.
Sorry about that.  21. They shake hands.
So where do you stand on civil rights, blood?
Don’t mind Booker, he’s just angry his name is Booker.
Of all the goddamn names!
I thought we weren’t supposed to discuss politics.
Out there in the White House, but you in the black house now, boy, and I’m just a blood that’s curious where the other blood stand.
You don’t have to answer, Cecil, no one else does. Cecil turns to Booker, smiles with warmth.
I don’t think those negroes down South want any more trouble than they've already got.
Amen to that! Carter high fives Cecil. Fast friends. Booker smiles.

That's alright, that’s alright. (Upper crust voice) Now if you gentleman will excuse me, the First Family needs their filet mignon and Grand Mariner. A pleasure meeting you, Mr. Gains. He bows his head, then walks out. Carter smiles at Cecil.
Welcome to the House.  22.

Cecil and Fallows stand in the State Dining Room, an eleg room with ornate gold curtains, gold chandelier and a mas portrait of Abraham Lincoln over the marble fire place. They hover over a dinning table covered in the finest chi crystal and flatware. Freddie points to the crystal glass
The glasses are always placed in the following order: Water, white, red and flute. Always serve from the left and when lifting a plate-- He leans in from the left and effortlessly lifts the plat
--you must never scrape the bottom. The tinkle of silverware will get an immediate report to me which I report to the Chief Usher. Cecil nods, but it’s clear that this is serious business.
You must never listen or react to a conversation. The room should feel--
--emptier when I’m in it. Freddie nods.

And never ever rush service, because Mrs. Eisenhower is watching you like a hawk. As if on cue, the door opens and in walks MAMIE EISENHOWE 59, with her SOCIAL SECRETARY. In a sundress, Mamie dress youthful with curly bangs, but she acts like a general.
Freddie, I just finished tonight's menus. I’ve decided to change asparagus to green beans. The Social Secretary hands Freddie the menus.
Very good, Mrs. Eisenhower. Allow me to introduce our new butler, Cecil Gains.  23. Cecil gives a slight head bow.
A true honor, Mrs. Eisenhower.

Never rush service, Cecil, and you'll be alright with me. (Turns to Freddie) Speaking of which, at the Navy dinner, I noticed that on three separate occasions, Roger picked up courses too soon. This is the third time I’ve mentioned his service.
It is unacceptable, Mrs. Eisenhower and I assure you that his presence will no longer be required. Cecil looks surprised, it’s cutthroat here. Mamie feels b
Oh, now, that’s not necessary, Freddie, give him one more shot.
I prefer not, Mrs. Eisenhower, he has tried both our patience.
Well...if you insist. Mamie smiles at Cecil, flipping from General to hostess.
Welcome to the House, Cecil, I hope your time here is pleasurable. And with that, she moves on as quickly as she came.
Let's begin, shall we.

Cecil is in the small kitchen with steel appliances and cabinets. He places a teapot on a silver tray as the STAF black, shoot him glances, they know it’s his first servin As he lifts the tray, a photographer takes a picture of h to record the moment. He looks fantastic in his fitted tu holding a beautiful tea set. Freddie whispers in his ear:  24.
You hear nothing, you see nothing, you only serve.
Cecil walks down the hall to the corridor entrance of the Oval Office. A tiny bead of sweat forms on his forehead.
He walks into the corridor, a SECRET SERVICE AGENT stops
Tea for the president.

Cecil walks in to the Oval Office and sees DWIGHT D. EISENHOWER standing upright at attention by his desk. His presence is enormous, but he exudes a grandfatherly warmt Cecil tries not to stare at him, but it’s hard not to. He sets the tray down and begins to pour a cup of tea. Two other men are seated on the sofas - the Chief of Staf SHERMAN ADAMS, 56, tough and harsh, is in an argument wit Attorney General, HERBERT BROWNELL, 51, calm and low keye
So what are you suggesting? Sending federal troops to Little Rock?

If it comes to that, then yes. Cecil picks up the cup and saucer, but it rattles as his SHAKES from nerves. He grips the cup with the other hand stop the rattling and carefully sets it down on Ike’s des Ike steps forward, his presence overtakes the room.

No, no, no. I can’t see any situation where I’d send troops to the South. Ever. It would cause another Civil War. Cecil begins to pour another cup, his hand shakes even mo He’s not listening, totally focused on not spilling.  25.
If the Federal government doesn’t enforce Brown, then who will? The South must comply with the law.

The South has been in compliance with the law for the last 60 years. They've built their entire society around the law. Then, in one day, that damn fool Earl Warren tells them their entire way of life is now illegal. It’s going to take some time for them to adjust. Cecil pours another cup, but a tiny bit of tea pours over edge. He quickly takes out a napkin and drys the saucer.

I understand, Mr. President, but if Faubus continues to block the negro children, then we must enforce the Constitution. Cecil places a cup of tea in front of Sherman Adams, tryi to be as obsequious as possible.
Let’s give Faubus more time. With a little persuading, he’1ll back down. We just want to move slowly. Ike sips his tea as he struggles through his feelings.
I am for moderation...but I am also for progress. (Then) That is exactly what I am for. Cecil grabs his tray and hurries out of the room.
Walking out of the Oval Office, sweat freely pours down Cecil’s face. He dabbles a handkerchief on his forehead. CECIL V.O. I was so scared I didn’t hear one word those men said.  26.
Cecil serves Gloria, Louis and Elroy dinner as everyone listens with rapture.
Then my hands started shakin’.
Did you spill, Mr. Gains?
A little, but I cleaned it before anyone saw.
What did the President talk about?
You know I can’t tell anyone that. Gloria nods, a little disappointed, but understands.
Butlers know secrets?
They know everything, but they tell nothing. That’s the butler’s code. Elroy grins, very exciting. Louis clears his throat, loud
You got a bone in your throat or you got something to say? Louis takes out a flyer and hands it to his dad, it reads ‘MAMIE TILL, MOTHER OF EMMET TILL, SPEAKS OUT!’
I really want to go to this.
Absolutely not. No way.
How come?
Nuthin’ good can come goin’ to this sort of thing. Nuthin’. I’m sorry, Louis, the answer is no. Gloria glances at Louis who can’t hide his disappointment  27.
Gloria and Louis are in a packed African-American church.

You promise you won’t tell your father I brought you here? Louis nods, so thrilled to be there. Up on the stage walk MAMIE TILL, 34, black, pretty. The audience gives her a w round of applause. She walks to a podium next to a large black & white pictu on a pedestal of the smiling Emmet Till. On another pedes is the photo of his mutilated corpse. She speaks softly:
If I should cry for the rest of my life there wouldn’t be enough tears for my son Emmett Till. The audience yells ‘That’s right!’ and ‘Tell it like it i

I’m just a quiet house wife from Chicago, I never once saw myself as having the courage to stand up in front of people and speak my mind, but we can’t allow what happened to my boy to ever happen again! The audience jumps to its feet, screaming with fire. Loui yells, transformed by Mamie Till who looks right at him:

We all gonna be tested... Louis is taken aback, he never thought he would be tested INT. WHITE HOUSE - IKE’S BEDROOM —- MORNING Ike stands in front of his VALET, a Filipino man in a Nav uniform. The Valet buttons Ike’s shirt up for him. MAMIE TILL V.O. .--and only then will we see who is truly on the side of the righteous. Ike stares forward in deep thought, very conflicted. Cecil walks into the room with a coffee as the Valet take the President’s dirty pajamas and exits. Ike sips the cof  28.
Cecil, did you mind going to an all colored school?
I didn’t go to school, Mr. President, I grew up on a cotton farm. Ike stares at him for a beat, then nods. As Cecil turns t leave, he sees a furious Sherman Adams in the doorway.
What is it?
The State Guard just blocked all the colored kids from entering the school again.
Faubus promised me he’d let them in.
The Governor lied, Mr. President.
Ike sits behind his desk as he speaks directly into a TV camera. Sherman Adams and Herbert Brownell are in the roo

I have today issued an Executive Order directing the use of troops under Federal authority to aid in the execution of Federal law at Little Rock, Arkansas. Brownell shoots Sherman Adams a subtle look, Adams shrugs
Cecil, Booker and Carter watch the announcement with the dishwashers in the kitchen. Everyone has a look of pride.
‘Thus will restore the image of America and of all its parts as one nation...’  29.
Louis and Elroy walk to school as we hear Ike finish up: IKE V.O. “,..indivisible with liberty and justice for all.”
Does this mean we're all gonna go to white schools now?
Probably not right away, but I bet by the time I graduate high school, every school will be integrated.

I brought you a Fresca, Mr. President. LBJ looks back at him, smiles through his sadness.
Thank you, Cecil. He takes a huge swig, it makes him feel a little better.
How’s your boy doing? Cecil doesn’t answer immediately, tough to talk about Lou

I don’t know, Mr. President. Sometimes I feel like we’re living in two different worlds. All I want is for him to be safe, but no matter what I say, he always gets so angry at me. The Protestors get even louder:
He keeps telling me that I don’t understand him...and maybe he’s right. Maybe I just don’t understand him anymore. LBJ looks at Cecil with a deep pain. He feels the same wa about the country.
Sometimes it’s hard to be a father.
90 year old Cecil is ironing a pair of black pants.
Were you sad that LBJ didn’t run for a second term?  88. Cecil looks at his watch.
How much more time do we have? I don’t want to be late.
We've got a few more hours. (Then) Were you sad to see him go?
I’m always sad when the First Family leaves. Always.

The moving van is parked as Housemen carry LBJ'’s boxes t Right after a Houseman shuts the van door, it takes off. CECIL V.O. But I was also secretly excited that an old friend was comin’ back. An identical moving van immediately pulls up in its place hear the voice of the new President: RICHARD V.O. I, Richard Milhous Nixon, do solemnly swear...

Richard Nixon and his wife, PAT NIXON, 56, walk down the Center Hall flanked by staff and RD Warner. She is poised lean with a perfect blond coif. Pat is quiet, but not col They are taking a tour of their new living quarters led b Warner. He is flanked by a few aides and the Nixon daught TRICIA, 22, petite blond and JULIE, 20, brunette. Nixon smiles as he gives Cecil his signature Victory salu Cecil gives it back to him.

Gloria is in the kitchen, rolling dough for dinner. She l unhappy, perhaps something is missing from her life. Just then, there is a knock at the door. She opens it to see -  89. Louis and Carol. They both have afros and wear black pant and black leather jackets, a militant ‘black power’ look.
Hi, Ma. Gloria tears up at the site of her son, so excited to see him. She flings open the door and gives him a huge hug.
Ma, I want you to meet my fiance, Carol Blue. Gloria's eyes light up. She screams:
The dear lord has finally answered my prayers! She throws her arms around Carol, embracing her in a big

The entire family is having dinner along with several neighbors, including Gina and Elroy, who is dressed in a uniform. An impromptu welcome home party. There is a tension in the air as no one knows what to mak Louis and Carol’s ‘black power’ look. Cecil is particular put off. Louis glances at Elroy, hates his Navy uniform.
You goin’ to Vietnam?
Yes, sir. Gina puts her arm around him.
We all so proud. Everyone nods. Louis and Carol glance at each other, then back to their food, biting their tongues. More silence.
So, Carol, I have all sorts of cooking supplies you can have when you two move in together.
Thank you, Mrs. Gains, but I don’t cook.  90.
What?
The sisters in our political organization refuse to partake in traditional gender roles. This makes Gloria feel a little self conscious.
Oh, that’s very...unique.
What’s your political organization called?
The Black Panther Party. Silence.
What kind of name is that?
We promote Black Power through pride in our African heritage as expressed in the teachings and self discipline of Brothers Huey Newton and Bobby Seale.
We provide free breakfast for children, free medical clinics, and free self defense classes.
Self defense classes?
We ain’t gonna get beat no mo’. This lands like a hammer. The room looks uncomfortable.
That reminds me of a movie I just saw that you might like. ‘In the Heat of the Night’. Sidney Poitier plays a cop that goes Sout--
I won’t see anything with Sidney Poitier.  gl.
Why not?
Sidney Poitier is the white man’s fantasy of what he wants the black to be. Well behaved with no sense of his manhood as a sexual being.
But his movies have him fighting for equal rights.

Only in a way that is acceptable to the white status quo. He earns the white man’s respect with false dignity instead of fighting against the immorality of his degradation. (Then) And the brother can’t act. Carol and him laugh. Cecil looks upset.
He won the Academy Award...he’s broken barriers for our people.
By being white, by acting white. Sidney Poitier is nothing but a rich Uncle Tom. Cecil jumps to his feet and screams:
Honey!

head_text.subj: I WILL NOT SIT HERE AND HAVE YOU
RIDICULE THE GREATEST NEGRO STAR OF

text: HE’S AN UNCLE TOM! Cecil SMASHES a plate.
I’M SORRY, BUTLER! I DIDN’T MEAN TO
Gloria SLAPS Louis across the face. Hard. Gina gasps.

Never disrespect your father in this house. NEVER! Everything you have is because of him. Everything! Your father is a saint and you will treat him with respect! Silence. Then, Louis laughs, nods to Carol to leave.
Shit, alright. I’m gone. You negroes be good, while me and my girl get y'all some mo’ rights.
Get out.
So long, pops.
Just get out. Louis and Carol turn around and walk out of the devastate room. Cecil stares at them, fuming in anger.
Cecil walks down a hall with a tray of tea, the anger and bitterness still plastered across his face. Right when he turns into the room, his face instantly fli to his pleasant smile.
Cecil brings in a tea for Nixon who is deep in conversati with his two closest advisors - BOB HALDEMAN, 44, crew cu intense, and JOHN EHRLICHMAN, 45, balding, boy scout face
We think the time calls for a period of benign neglect. Cecil pours tea for Nixon.  93.
Benign neglect?
The polls overwhelmingly show white voters are tired of the race issue and feel enough has been done. Cecil pours tea for Ehrlichman, glances at him, but Ehrlichman doesn’t notice.
And the Southern Strategy is clearly working. We gained momentum in ‘68, but we think we can flip the South for good in ‘72. Nixon thinks it over, stares at Cecil who pours tea.

There’s this whole black power movement going on, right? What if Nixon promotes black power to mean black businesses, and we find ways to support black entrepreneurs. We pass the buck on desegregation to the courts, but push black enterprise to win over the 20% that could vote our way. Haldeman and Erhlichman exchange glances, they love it.
That’s excellent, sir. Cecil picks up his tray and heads for the door.
We just need to make sure that ‘Nixon’s black power’ doesn’t equate Nixon with the Black Panthers. Cecil pauses for a slight beat.
God no! Did you read Hoover's memo?! It’s terrifying. I gave him the green light to go after them with all we got. Cecil’s eyes shut in pain as he walks out the door.  94.
Ten BLACK PANTHERS, all in black jackets and berets, load shotguns in a smoked filled room. The leader of this grou ELDRIDGE HUDGINS, 29, black, muscular, loads his shotgun.
Always beware of the nigger with a gun. A few people in the room laugh, but Louis is uncomfortabl He looks around at the guns, the smoke, just doesn’t like what he sees. He whispers to Carol.
I got to talk to you.
Louis speaks to Carol in the hall outside the room.
We should get out of here.
What?
This is a mistake. We should go.
What the hell are you talking about?
I was always proud to be in jail...but I don’t think I’d be proud to be there for what we're about to do. Carol looks stunned. Eldridge Huggins sticks his head out
Is there a problem here?
Louis wants to leave. Eldridge Huggins stares at him.
You scared, brother?  95.
Yeah, I’m scared, and I’m not your brother.
What about you, soul sister? You gonna go with this jive ass peckerwood? Carol looks at Louis, then at Eldridge Huggins.
No, soul brother, I’m with you. She walks over to Huggins and puts her arm around him.
I’m not getting beat no mo’, Louis.
Louis walks down a quiet Oakland street, deeply disturbed POLICE CAR slowly drives by him, then continues on its wa Louis watches the car for a moment, then runs after it.
The Panthers are staked out with their shotguns - one beh a tree, two behind a house, three more behind a fence. Ca grips her shotgun, but now she looks unsure.
Louis runs toward the police car that’s half a mile down street. He waves his arms at the police car.

The police car slowly drives down the block looking for a address, inching closer toward its assassins. The Panthers give each other slight nods. Carol nods back but she’s starting to sweat, doesn’t want to do this now. Right when the car gets in their cross hairs, the Panther start BLASTING away. BANG! BANG! BANG! Carol watches for a second, then starts BLASTING as she screams in rage.  96. Louis appears at the head of the block and sees the firin squad. Police sirens can be heard off in the distance as Panthers immediately take off running. Carol sees Louis at the head of the block. They stare at other, Carol with shame in her eyes. Then she runs off. Louis watches her go as the sirens get louder and louder. Finally, he runs away. EXT. CECIL’S NEIGHBORHOOD - DAY Cecil drives down the street that still has many burnt do buildings from the ‘68 riot. A few new storefronts have opened that sell incense, candles and African clothes. Men and woman have AFROS and wear colorful DASHIKIS. A se of AFRICAN PRIDE has been infused into the neighborhood. Cecil eyes it all, just doesn’t know what to make of it.
Cecil walks into the house and sees Gloria on the couch watching news coverage of Watergate. NEWSCAST V.O. “The White House continues to deny any involvement in the break in at the Watergate hotel.”
Can you please turn that off? I have to deal with Watergate everyday at work, I don’t want to deal with it at home.
Well, I can’t live in ignorance just because your boss is a two bit criminal with a gang of Cuban thugs on his payroll.
A gang of what?
The plumbers.
The what?  97.
Nixon’s henchmen. The same guys that broke into Daniel Ellsberg’s psychiatrist office were behind the Watergate break-in’s, it’s obvious this is a conspiracy.
What do you want me to do about it? Quit?
Of course not.
Cuz if the staff quit every time a President did something we didn’t like, there’d be no staff! Gloria feels bad, kisses him on the mouth.
I’m sorry, baby. The whole thing just makes me upset.
And when did you start getting so worked up about politics?

When he didn’t appoint a black cabinet member. Not one single black man in his entir-- Just then - they see a MILITARY CAR drive slowly down the street. They hurry to the window to see the car pull up t house. Out walks a MILITARY OFFICER and a PRIEST.

Oh my god. Cecil and Gloria hurry out of the house, they look terrif Many neighbors are coming out of their homes as the Offic and Priest knock on a front door. The door opens revealing Gina, she stares at them in mort fear. Before they can speak she screams:
No! Not my Elroy! No! Cecil has hurried over and holds her as she WAILS in pain  98.
Please God! Not my Elroy! NOT MY
The neighbors all surround Gina, many are crying. Cecil continues to hold Gina as she wails in his arms. CECIL V.O. I never felt more lost in all my life.

90 year old Cecil ties a black tie around his shirt colla CECIL V.O. Everything was changin’ around me so fast. Vietnam took our Elroy and Gloria was startin’ to drift away. (Then) Everywhere I turned, someone new was leavin’ me behind...
Nixon stands in front of the entire White House staff wit Pat and his two daughters.

I want you all to know that I leave with deep regret in my heart. You lifted me up during the tough moments and for that I will always be grateful. Several of the staff are crying, but not Cecil. He stares Nixon with a bitter detachment.
We think that when we suffer a defeat, that all is ended. He looks right at Cecil.
But the greatness comes when you are really tested... Cecil looks surprised, never thought he’d ever be tested.  99.
.--because only if you've been in the deepest valley...

The Houseman shuts the back of the moving van. NIXON V.O. ...Can you ever know how magnificent it is to be on the highest mountain. Right as the moving van drives off, an identical moving v pulls up in its place. We hear the voice of GERALD FORD:
I, Gerald Rudolph Ford, do solemnly swear-— The moving van immediately pulls off and a new moving van pulls up right where it was parked. We hear the distinct southern twang of our next President:
I, Jimmy Carter, do solemnly Swear...

The staff hurries through the Central Hall, bringing in t Carter’s new furniture that has a distinct country flair. The new Chief Usher, SCOTT REXFORD, mid-40’s, clean cut, oversees the melee, he is much warmer than RD Warner.
38 minutes to go. You all are doing great! Willie Nelson’s ‘On the Road Again’, plays over the seque
The new President, JIMMY CARTER, 52, cherub-like, exudes warmth and charm. He feels like a sweet uncle. He wears a apron as he pours green water from a pot into a bowl.  100.

The juice from the collared greens contains an abundance of the vegetable’s minerals and vitamins. (Big smile) We call it pot likker. The Chef grins, but a little worried that his culinary sk are going to be under utilized for the next four years.
‘On the Road Again’ continues as Jimmy’s daughter, AMY, 9 round nerdy glasses, roller skates through the Cross Hall Cecil jumps out of the way holding a tray.

A huge Southern style BBQ is taking place on the South La with a crawfish boil, piles of corn bread and BBQ. WILLIE NELSON is up on a stage singing ‘On The Road Again’. Jimmy dances with his wife, ROSALYN, pretty and charming.
Jimmy Carter stands at a podium in front of the press cor

.--and that is why I am proud to appoint the country’s first black female Cabinet member, Patricia Harris, as head of Housing and Urban Development. PATRICIA HARRIS, 52, black, walks up to the podium. Cecil applauds, then stops, remembering he’s not supposed to cl
Gloria beams with pride at a big front page photo on the Washington Post of Patricia Harris. She looks up, thinking...this sparks something in her.

Gloria walks into the office of the Combahee River Collective. It’s filled with young black woman in their 2 and 30’s. Many of them with bushy Afros.  101. Posters cover the walls with pictures of black women marc in rallies with the slogan - “A SEPARATE ROAD TO FEMINISM female STAFF MEMBER look up at the older Gloria.
Can I help you? Gloria doesn’t respond, she looks nervous.
Gloria sits in a small office across from BARBARA SMITH, wears an army jacket. She has a tough, but cool vibe.

Our goal is to gain female equality by calling attention to racism, sexism, homophobia and classicism to ensure that the most discriminated individual in American society, the black woman, will no longer be ignored. Gloria has a stunned look on her face, doesn’t know what say. Barbara Smith can tell she is overwhelmed. BARBARA SMITH (CONT’D) So tell me, Gloria, what exactly brought you here?
Well, my son was a civil rights activist in the sixtie--

The black woman was completely left behind by the Civil Rights movement. It was always ‘One Man, One Vote’, the word ‘woman’ was never mentioned even though we were an integral part of the struggle. Slight beat. BARBARA SMITH (CONT’D) I’m sorry, go ahead.
I just feel like I’ve spent the last 20 years watching the world go by on my television. (Then) I don’t want to watch no more.  102. Barbara Smith smiles at Gloria, likes her.
I think you’d fit in nicely here.
You don’t think I’m too old?
You're never too old to fight for social justice. (Then) So what is your son doing these days? Gloria goes quiet.
We haven't spoken in a while.

Dressed in a suit and tie, Louis stands at a podium in fr of a medium sized audience of about 100 people. A banner above him announces ‘STATE ASSEMBLY DEBATE’. The room is sparsely decorated, a low budget operation, b Louis passionately addresses the modest crowd. In his mid 30's now, he’s lost a little hair and gained a few pounds

With the economy spiraling out of control, there is no greater time for Affirmative Action than now. I know these measures are not popular with white voters, as they seem to feel that racism is a thing of the past, but the truth is that black America is still significantly disadvantaged due to past and present discrimination. The MODERATOR turns to Louis main competitor, KEITH ALANS black conservative in a bow tie, he speaks from a podium.
Mr. Gains and I may share the same skin color, but that is all we share. Affirmative Action is racism in reverse and it only creates more hostility by causing whites to resent blacks. (MORE )
If the black man wants to succeed he must do it with his own achievements.
You can’t kick a man in the dirt for 400 years and then accuse him of being dirty.
Even our liberal President agrees that Affirmative Action should be phased out as he has already begun slashing these programs. Louis shoots him an icy look.
To my great disappointment, President Carter is not a liberal.

Jimmy Carter sits across from the Black Congressional Cau They are stern with him, all look frustrated. Their leade REP. JOHN CONYERS, 49, tough, no nonsense. Cecil refills everyone's glasses with waters. He seems focused on the water, but it’s clear he’s listening.
You received 94% of the black vote in the second closest election of the century, Mr. President. We elected you, and I’m sorry to say that we feel betrayed by these cuts to social programs.
My first priority has got to be getting inflation down or the economy is going to continue to spiral out of control.
Which is exactly why we need more economic investment in the inner cities, not less. White businesses have fled in droves and it has created rampant black unemployment.  104.
It’s not just the black community that is suffering--
--but we are disproportionately affected.
I've got to keep the budgets tight, everyone is just going to have to learn to get by with less. The black leaders exchange frustrated glances. John Conye rises to his feet. Cecil looks surprised.
We’re used to getting less, Mr. President, we were just hoping for more from you. He walks out of the room, Cecil looks stunned.
The small campaign headquarters is covered in deflated balloons that matches everyone’s deflated spirit. The onl person not upset is Louis who tries to cheer everyone up.

I know everyone is disappointed, and no one more so than me. But we have to remember that even though we lost tonight, we need to celebrate that another brother has won an election. Now I know he may not be our kind of brother... Everyone laughs.
..-but a black man is going to the state assembly and for that we should all be thrilled. Polite applause.
Ten years ago we couldn’t even vote in the South and now we’ve got brothers and sisters in Congress and state offices. (MORE )

Maynard Jackson is the mayor of Atlanta, Tom Bradley in Los Angeles, Carl Stokes, Shirley Chisolm, Barbara Jordan and the list goes on and on! We are doing it! We are starting to live the American dream! Everyone is applauding like crazy now. Even though Louis lost, he looks like a leader.

I’ve been through so many dark times, but in all those years gettin’ beat and thrown in prison, I never thought I’d see the day that I would have to give a concession speech. The room gives a warm and joyous applause to this.

I want to thank you all for your hard work, and I want to thank my beautiful wife, Sarah, for all those long hours on the trail. Everyone applauds Louis’ gorgeous wife, SARAH, 30, black. smiles at the crowd.
This isn’t the end tonight, it’s only the beginning.
Cecil is on the phone as Gloria anxiously waits for news. Cecil’s eyes drop, so do Gloria’s.
Thank you, I appreciate it. He hangs up, turns to his wife. Then sadly shakes his hea
He lost 51 to 49%. Gloria cringes at how close it was.
Should we call him?  106.
It’s been so long. Do you think he wants to hear from us tonight? Gloria shrugs, isn’t sure.
The room has emptied out a bit. Louis lounges on a couch, arms clutched around Sarah.
I still can’t believe I lost to that honky nigger. She busts up laughing.
Everyone knows the fool only got into Harvard because of Affirmative Action! What’s the matter with these people?! An AIDE yells from the other end of the room.
Louis, you got a phone call. Louis walks over to the phone, picks it up. He hears: CAROL V.O. I’m so sorry you lost. Louis sits up, obviously hasn’t heard from her in years.
Where are you?
Carol is in a prison uniform in a federal penitentiary. H arms are covered in prison tatoos, she’s been here for ye
I love you, Louis. I’m sorry I never could say that before, but I really do love you.
What happened? Where did you go?  107.

Don’t ever forget that, okay, baby, please don’t ever forget it. She hangs up. Louis slowly hangs up the phone, then looks over at his w He smiles at his beautiful Sarah...happy with his life. EXT. CECIL’S NEIGHBORHOOD - WASHINGTON DC - DAY Driving to work, Cecil sees several boarded up buildings ‘FOR RENT’ and ‘FORECLOSED’ signs. All of the African-Pri stores have shut down and no new businesses are moving in CECIL V.O. Every where I looked, it seemed like another black man was losin’ somethin’ new.

Cecil eyes the headline on Booker’s newspaper: ‘SUPREME C RULES FOR BAKKE, ENDS RACIAL QUOTAS.” CECIL V.O. And for the first time, I was startin’ to get mad. INT. WHITE HOUSE - CHIEF USHER’S OFFICE - DAY Cecil sits across from the Chief Usher, Scott Rexford.

I’ve been here for twenty years now, and for all that time, the black help has been getting a smaller salary than the white help. I just don’t think it’s right. Scott Rexford is much warmer than the previous Chief Ushe
I don’t think it is either, Cecil.
And there are black housemen who should be engineers by now, they should've been promoted years ago.  108.
I fully agree, and I plan on making several promotions immediately. The raises are going to be tougher because of the recession. Cecil smiles his warm smile.

I know that we’re in a recession, but I can’t wait out these excuses anymore. I have to be paid the same as the white help or I’1l have to move on. Silence. Scott Rexford is impressed at his forcefulness.
I know that no one wants that, including the President. I’1l get into it immediately.
It’s important that it’s not just me, all of the black help needs to get equal pay to the white staff. Scott Rexford smiles.
We'll find a way to make this work.

Cecil walks up the stair landing with a small look of pri on his face, he sees Jimmy Carter sitting on the floor of Treaty Room tieing a fly fishing fly. Cecil stares at the President, he looks beaten up by the depressed. Jimmy sees Cecil through the doorway.
You ever do much fishing, Cecil?
No, sir.
My daddy used to take me fly fishing as a boy. (Then) (MORE )
I bet when I’m on my death bed, I‘1l think of my daddy, and I probably won’t even remember I was President. Cecil grins, but the conversation is a touch painful.
Were you close with your father? Cecil shakes his head, no.
I never knew him.
I’m sorry, Cecil, that’s a real shame.
I sometimes wonder what he looked like.
If he could see you now, I bet he’d be real proud of you.
I bet your father would be very proud of you, Mr. President. Slight beat.
I think he might be disappointed.
I don’t think so, Mr. President. His son made it to the White House.
We both made it, Cecil.
Yes we did, Mr. President. Slight beat, Jimmy’s face falls knowing his doomed fate.
Except you’ll get to stay.  110.
A moving van is pulling out as a new moving van pulls in. hear the raspy older voice of our next president:
I, Ronald Wilson Reagan, do solemnly swear...
RONALD ‘RONNIE’ REAGAN, 69, exudes a sweet, likable quali He feels like a favorite Grandfather. He is in the kitche with the butlers and the kitchen staff telling them a jok

So the psychiatrist took the pessimistic brother to a room piled to the ceiling with brand-new toys. But instead of yelping with delight, the little boy burst into tears. "What's the matter? Don't you want to play with any of the toys,” asked the psychiatrist. "Yes," the little boy bawled, "but if I did I'd only break them." The staff is smiling, a few have already started laughing

Next the psychiatrist treated the optimistic brother. Trying to dampen his out look, he took him to a room piled to the ceiling with horse manure. The optimist yelped with delight, clambered to the top of the pile and began gleefully digging out scoop after scoop with his bare hands. A few people grimace, but Cecil is laughing. Ronnie start chuckle as he nears the punch line.

"What do you think you're doing?", the psychiatrist asked. (Then) "With all this manure," the optimistic boy replied, "there must be a pony in here somewhere!"  111. The whole room bust out in laughter, everyone is beaming, they love Ronald Reagan. Just then, his wife, NANCY, 59, walks into the room in a stylish red suit. As soon as she walks in, Ronnie tenses up a touch, become different person around Nancy.
Good talking to everyone. He pecks Nancy on the cheek as he hurries out of the room Booker whispers to Cecil:
Just like at my house.

Ronnie sits with PAT BUCHANAN, 47, jowly, the Communicati Director. They are across from three Republican Senators, RICHARD LUGAR, 53, BOB DOLE, 62 and NANCY KASSEBAUM, 53. Cecil pours tea for Senator Dole who smiles at him.
I want to make myself clear on this issue. If Congress passes sanctions against South Africa, I will be forced to veto those sanctions. Cecil stops pouring for a split second, then starts up ag
Mr. President, we feel that you are missing a major point here.
Which is what, Senator Lugar? Cecil pours tea for Senator Kassebaum who nods at him.
The brutal repression of South Africa’s black citizens is no longer just a foreign policy issue. It’s a domestic civil rights issue. Pat Buchanan snaps at him.

If we impose sanctions on South African it will make us appear weak to Russia!  112. Cecil stands at the back, staring forward, it’s clear he’ listening. Senator Kassebaum turns to Ronnie with urgency

Mr. President, the three of us are Senators from your own party, you can’t get a friendlier room than this. That is why we feel so comfortable telling you that South Africa is a human rights disaster. Blacks are beaten, tortured and gunned down in the streets. The America people are horrified by Apartheid. Ronnie looks frustrated with the Senators.
I’m sorry, Senator Kassebaum, but I will not show weakness to Russia by backing down on this issue.

But Mr. President, your own personal world leadership is at stake. The United States of America needs to be on the right side of history on the race issue. Ronnie looks at them all with his iron will, when he is convinced he’s right, nothing can change his mind.

Let me be clear so that there’s no confusion, if Congress passes this bill, I will veto it. Period. Pat Buchanan smiles at the three Republican Senators who stare at Ronnie, they can’t believe it. Cecil also stares at Ronnie, he can’t believe it either.
Cecil pours out the left over tea from his teapot. He loo disturbed on a deep level.
Ronnie sits alone behind his desk, he is writing a check for $2000. Cecil walks in.  113.
Yes, Mr. President.
I have a secret mission for you, Cecil.
Yes, sir.

I like to send people money when they write me about their financial problems, but my staff has been trying to get me to stop. You think you could help me keep this going? Ronnie places the check in an envelope and hands it to Ce
Absolutely, Mr. President. Ronnie looks up at him, something on his mind.
Cecil, did you ever go to those civil rights rallies in the sixties?
No, sir, I was too old for that sort of thing.
I know what you mean. Ronnie looks troubled, trying to work through his feeling
This whole civil rights issue...I sometimes fear I’m on the wrong side of it...that I’m just wrong. He turns to Cecil, a touch lost.
What do you think? Cecil stares at him, amazed.
90 year old Cecil stares into the video camera, still ama  114.
Never in my life had a President of the United States asked me what I thought about anything.
So what did you tell him?
I told him the truth.
Cecil smiles at the President with understanding.
I sometimes think the same thing about myself, Mr. President. Ronnie nods. Then points at the envelope with the check -
I appreciate your help with our little project. And don’t tell Nancy about it.
I won’t, Mr. President.
As Cecil walks into the hallway he hears from behind him.
Cecil. Cecil tenses up, quickly puts the envelope in his pocket.
Yes, Mrs. Reagan?

You're very well liked around here. Everyone says you’re the man that got them raises and promotions. I had no idea you were such a rebel. How'd you get to be like that? Cecil smiles, trying to play it off like a joke.  115.
I’m not a rebel, Mrs. Reagan, it just seemed like it was time. She smiles at him, clearly likes Cecil.
I wanted to talk to you because I’d like to personally invite you to the State Dinner next week.
But I’m going to be there, Mrs. Reagan.
No, Cecil, not as a butler, I’m inviting you as a guest. Cecil is stunned, doesn’t know what to say.
But...the President prefers for me to serve him personally.
Don’t worry about, Ronnie. I‘11l take care of that. So we’ll see you and your wife next week, yes?
(Stunned) Yes, Ma’m.
Wearing a three piece tux, Cecil walks out of his house w Gloria who is in a ball gown. They are greeted with a wil round of applause from the neighbors who are all outside.
Gloria is being escorted by a Military aide toward the Ea Room. She looks around in total amazement, Cinderella at ball. Cecil wanders behind her like all the other male da
Can I get you champagne, Mr. Gains? Cecil slaps him on the shoulder.  116.
Oh, come on now! Booker starts to laugh. Then from behind them they hear:

Ladies and Gentleman, the President and First Lady of the United States. The Military Band begins ‘Hail to the Chief’ as Ronnie an Nancy walk down the hall to great fanfare. Gloria stares at Nancy who greets all of her guests with charisma. Gloria is in awe of Nancy as she whispers to Ce
She’s so strong.
They are seated at separate tables as all of the butlers smile at Cecil, very proud. A BUTLER serves him tomato so
This one is made special, Mr. Gains.
